title: Recap
section: Overall workflow for a Bayesian analysis
text:
Overall workflow for a Bayesian analysis

Decide on an appropriate likelihood function.
Decide on priors for all parameters in the likelihood function.
Use the model that results from this combination of likelihood and priors to derive the posterior distribution of each parameter.
Draw inferences about your research question absed on the posterior distribution of the parameter of interest.

We’ll see this in action tomorrow!

title: Learning objectives for Day 1
text:
How does Bayesian reasoning work? 
What’s the anatomy of a Bayesian model?  
How do different priors influence the model’s estimates?  
How does Bayesian inference differ from frequentist inference?

title: Recap and take-aways
text:
Take-aways

Practice dealing with uncertainty.
What does a frequentist model do that a Bayesian model does not do? NHST vs. effect size estimation.

What is the difference between effect size estimation and hypothesis testing?

What options are out there for Bayesian hypothesis testing?


What does a Bayesian model do that a frequentist model does not do?

Licenses more flexible interpretations, since we’re not stuck in the binary of “reject the null or not”.

Why do some people prefer Bayesian analyses?
Why is Bayes currently up and coming? / Why are frequentist models the standard?

title: Learning objectives for Day 2
text:
What is the workflow for running a Bayesian analysis?

How do we decide what likelihood to use?
How do we decide what prior(s) to use?

How does the model work out the posterior?
How do we implement and fit a Bayesian model using brms?
How would we report the results in a publication?

title: A crash course in Bayesian inference
text:
What you can expect from this two-day workshop:

Learn the conceptual whys and wherefores of Bayesian inference.
Get hands-on practice fitting Bayesian models in R using brms.
Have some discussions as well as some individual work time.

Intended audience:

You know how to use R and RStudio.
You are familiar with linear regression models and want to know how to think about them from a Bayesian perspective.

To be able to run the code we’ll use, please follow the set-up instructions here, and make sure everything is running before the workshop begins.

Thanks to n loewen for help coming up with the workshop name :)

title: Elizabeth’s recommended resources
text:
For total newcomers to stats in R:

Materials from Stefano Coretta’s Statistical and Quantitative Methods course from this past winter (partly developed by yours truly!).

For people seeking intuitions and lots of detail presented approachably:

Statistical Rethinking by Richard McElreath.

This book doesn’t use brms, but here’s a translation into brms + tidyverse by A Solomon Kurz.

McElreath has a series of free lectures too.

For people seeking more formalisation and math:

An Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis for Cognitive Science by Bruno Nicenboim, Daniel Schad, and Shravan Vasishth.

This book is my stats bible ♥️


And work I don’t have personal experience with but that others say is helpful:

A Student’s Guide to Bayesian Statistics by Ben Lambert
